posts.cooked: A system integrating with standard FTC Can systems is needed, preferably Python-based though not critical. The budget is under $250, avoiding the RoboRiot 2 model. Applications involve a turret bot on a non-Swerve drive base, potentially using Talon FXs and Spark Maxes. No experience required beyond basic knowledge.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
The text supports SocketCan on CTRE’s website. If you’re controlling TalonFXs or TalonFXS’s SocketCan is feasible.  

RomiRobot used Raspberry Pi and offers modeling of PWM or self-building solutions. Additional resources include guides on setting up CAN and PWM on Raspberry Pi.  

There are various forums and documentation such as Flux, Influx Technology, and PragmaticLinux offering detailed instructions and troubleshooting.  

These platforms provide comprehensive guides for configuring hardware and software for effective control systems.

Joemost suggests either following the model of PWM or doing your own thing. Gerthworm notes that both motors mentioned allow control via PWM without sensor feedback, asking if this suffices. The author expresses uncertainty about using PWM with talons but finds it likely works better than the planned CAN system. posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Given how open the Phoenix protocols are, that's where I would start, then rev because there's a surprising number of their protocols available publicly.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Given how open the phoenix protocols are that’s where I would start t  

This was something I actually didn’t know. For what it’s worth I did a bit of googling and wasn’t able to find a specific page that documented all the messages and their meaning.  

At a minimum the heartbeat protocol is definitely **not** intended to be public and would need some reverse engineering or disablement.  

I wasn’t sure it the talons could use pwm  

Yup! See [Bring Up: Talon FX/SRX and Victor SPX — Phoenix documentation](https://v5/docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/ch13_MC.html) - there’s a note in the box.  

With how Frc does can is that t just more setup for a Roborio interface ig or like hardware client?  

Today’s RIO CAN stack looks something like:  

physical bus → transciever → CPU → NI’s Stack → WPILib and/or Vendor libraries → User code (ex: `motor.getVelocity()`)  

There’s plenty of transceivers that work with cheaper CPU’s so that’s not too hard to do. The part that’s still on the user is to emulate the NI/Wpilib/Vendor library functionality to get all the way back to useful data.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: The heartbeat protocol is disabled when using C-TRE devices for non-FRC, and there are steps online on how to unfreeze the FRC lock on C-TRE hardware.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
The assistant has effectively cleaned and reformatted the text, ensuring that the output is clear, concise, and maintains the original meaning. By removing unnecessary elements and adjusting formatting minimally, they have produced a polished version suitable for its intended purpose.

**Cleaned Text:**

Upside it was just part of the Lifeboat/framework gui tools. When you set a new non-roborio robot controller and flashed it with the image you then could also see connectedPhoenix compatible devices and reset any sticky faults (FRC locks).  

I kept a hero board around as my firmware flasher which could lock and unlock from FRC mode and serve as a standalone CAN to USB hub. Then I'd connect the devices back to my Canable/Jetson Nano/Raspberry Pi with thePhoenix Framework running.  

Both methods work, when doing it for 40+ motor controllers it was best to have the standalone device.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: The heartbeat protocol is definitely not intended to be public and would require reverse engineering or disabling. Maybe something like the Saleae Logic Analyzer would work for this purpose. It’s available at half price for students and supports native CAN and a user-created plugin for CAN-FD. I’m considering purchasing one myself to work on CAN-related projects; it’s really helpful to see the actual outputs.

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked: To summarize what others have said, for Talon FX’s, you have two options: PWM Control and CAN Control. PWM Control requires a controller supporting standard hobby-style PWM outputs, which is cost-effective and compatible with microcontrollers like Arduino, though it's limited to output-only and simple duty cycle operations. For CAN Control, we support Phoenix 6 via SocketCAN on Linux and CANivore on both Linux and Windows. This allows controlling devices similar to FRC competition setups through Python or C++. Additionally, you can connect to the Raspberry Pi using Tuner for remote debugging and updates. If you have questions or face issues, feel free to reach out to our support team.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Logic analyzers with proper decoding can effectively reverse-engineer CAN Controller Area Network bus communication. Claims suggest the heartbeat feature can be disabled, yet other protocol aspects are already documented. Therefore, any further reverse-engineering efforts may be redundant.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: CANivore on Linux and Windows (exact requirements [link]). If I'm understanding this right, I could run a Raspberry Pi and CANivore and run that as a standard FRC control system style? Second question: Is there any true limit on how many devices the CANivore can handle? Third question: Would I still be able to use all encoders in the motors (ex. Kraken encoders)?

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
If I'm understanding this right, I could run a Raspberry Pi and Canivore as a standard FRC control system style. However, legally in competition, the robot controller must be the RoboRio until 2027, after which the system core takes over officially. For personal use, such as demo robots, it functions similarly, though it doesn't have the same timed robot functionality, relying instead on the Phoenix libraries rather than WPIlib. I don't have a good answer for number 2; my Canivore hasn't been stressed enough yet.  

For the third question, would I still be able to use all encoders in the motors? Yes, you can access these encoders or closed-loop control modes through the API, similar to how you'd handle them in regular robot code. An excellent example of the basics is available here: [GitHub](https://github.com/CrossTheRoadElec/Phoenix6-Linux-Example) and further details on the Phoenix6 hardware can be found at [CTRE Phoenix 6 C++: ctre::phoenix6::hardware::core::CoreTalonFX Class Reference](https://api.ctr-electronics.com/phoenix6/release/cpp/classctre_1_1phoenix6_1_1hardware_1_1core_1_1_core_talon_f_x.html).

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
Mr. Siefen’s corrections on points 1 and 3 are accurate, please refer to his responses for further clarification.

Regarding the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) and its legality concerning Raspberry Pi and CANivore setups, it is important to note that enabling devices for FRC purposes directly via the Raspberry Pi or CANivore is prohibited. However, utilizing the Raspberry Pi alongside a CANivore and roboRIO allows for device control through the roboRIO’s native communication channels. This configuration ensures compliance with FRC regulations while maintaining functional integration. Teams employing this approach acknowledge adherence to competition guidelines, thus avoiding any rule violations.

Additionally, when referencing non-FRC examples, consider exploring the Phoenix6-Examples repository for diverse feature implementations, which are designed to be adaptable to various WPI-Lib environments without extensive modifications.

A user query regarding device limits raises an interesting point: the CANivore does not impose explicit restrictions on the number of devices it can manage beyond available identifier (ID) space. While device IDs can theoretically range from 0 to 62 per model, duplication across models is permissible, such as assigning both a CANrange and Talon FX the same ID (e.g., ID 5). Users should monitor bandwidth consumption to prevent performance degradation, aiming for under 90% utilization to minimize frame loss. Adjusting update frequencies via the StatusSignal API helps optimize data transmission efficiency. As a baseline, around 45 Talon FX devices may experience issues on CANivore with default settings, suggesting the need for monitoring and configuration tuning.
